sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Influenza; Prophylaxis: Administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM annually
  • Influenza; Prophylaxis: (18 through 64 years) Administer 1 dose (0.1 mL) INTRADERMALLY annually
  • Influenza; Prophylaxis: (65 years or older; Fluzone(R) High-Dose) Administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM annually

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Usual dose: Administer 1 or 2 doses IM based on age and vaccine history; minimum age for vaccination is 6 months
  • Influenza; Prophylaxis: (9 years or older; Fluarix(R), Fluarix(R) Quadrivalent, Flulaval(R), Flulaval(R) Quadrivalent, Fluvarin(R), Fluzone(R), Fluzone(R) Quadrivalent) administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM annually
  • Influenza; Prophylaxis: (6 to 35 months; Fluzone(R), Fluzone(R) Quadrivalent) administer 1 dose (0.25 mL) IM or 2 doses (0.25 mL each) IM separated by at least 4 weeks, depending on vaccination history
  • Influenza; Prophylaxis: (3 to 8 years; Fluarix(R), Fluarix(R) Quadrivalent, Flulaval(R), Flulaval(R) Quadrivalent, Fluzone(R), Fluzone(R) Quadrivalent) administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM or 2 doses (0.5 mL each) IM separated by at least 4 weeks, depending on vaccination history
  • Influenza; Prophylaxis: (4 to 8 years; Fluvirin(R)) administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM or 2 doses (0.5 mL each) IM separated by at least 4 weeks, depending on vaccination history
  • Influenza; Prophylaxis: (5 to 8 years; Afluria(R)) administer 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM or 2 doses (0.5 mL) IM separated by at least 4 weeks if vaccination status unknown, vaccine-naive, or lacking vaccination with H1N1 antigen (ie, did not receive 2 or more doses since 2010 season); avoid use in children younger than 9 years due to the potential for fever or febrile seizures

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: Renal impairment, renal failure, ESRD, or hemodialysis-dependent: No dose adjustment required

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Influenza; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Exacerbation of asthma; Prophylaxis
  • Otitis media; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to neomycin (Afluria(R), Agriflu(R)), kanamycin (Agriflu(R)), or polymyxin (Afluria(R))
  • previous severe allergic reaction to vaccine or to any component of the vaccine, including egg proteins

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- syncope may occur, possibly accompanied by transient neurological signs (eg, visual disturbance, paresthesia, tonic-clonic limb movements), may occur
  • Hematologic:
  • -- patients with bleeding disorders (eg, hemophilia) or those receiving anticoagulant therapy have an increased risk of hematoma
  • Immunologic:
  • -- allergic reaction may occur in latex-sensitive individuals, as tip caps contain natural rubber latex
  • -- refer patients with hypersensitivity to egg protein to allergy specialist and perform risk assessment; monitoring recommended
  • -- immune response to vaccination may be lower in immunosuppressed patients, including those receiving immunosuppressive therapy
  • Neurologic:
  • -- consider risk vs benefit of administration if Guillain-Barre syndrome occurred within 6 weeks of previous vaccination
  • Other:
  • -- defer vaccination in patients with moderate to severe acute illness, with or without fever, unless the benefit outweighs the risk
  • -- increased risk of fever and febrile seizure in children (mostly younger than 5 years of age); use not recommended in children 6 months to 8 years of age; may use in patients aged 5 to 8 years with a condition that increases the risk of influenza complications only if no other vaccine is available

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (Adult, up to 76.4%; pediatric, up to 46%), Injection site induration (Adult, up to 58.4%; pediatric, up to 16.6%), Injection site mass (2% to 11%), Injection site pain (Adult, up to 64%; pediatric, up to 62%), Red color (adult, 10% to 23%; pediatric, 18% to 23%), Swelling at injection site (Adult, up to 56.8%; pediatric, up to 27%), Tenderness (adult, 34% to 60%; pediatric, 47.3% to 56.3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (adult, 1% or greater; pediatric, 2.5% to 15%), Loss of appetite (pediatric, 5% to 24%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (adult, 0.3% to 18%; pediatric, 6%), Myalgia (Adult, up to 34.1%; pediatric, up to 29%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (Adult, up to 33%; pediatric, up to 16.7%), Somnolence (Pediatric, 13% to 26.7%)
  • Psychiatric:Irritability (pediatric, 0.7% to 48%)
  • Other:Fatigue (adult, up to 21%; pediatric, 20%), Fever (Adult, less than 1% to 11%; pediatric, up to 37%), Malaise (Adult, 1% to 27.7%; pediatric, 14.6% to 20%), Shivering (Adult, 1% to 12.4%; pediatric, 3%)
Serious
Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    Do not inject IV
  • Intradermal
    • (Fluzone(R) intradermal, Fluzone(R) intradermal quadrivalent) gently shake injection system gently before use
    • (Fluzone(R) intradermal, Fluzone(R) intradermal quadrivalent) administer intradermally in the region of the deltoid muscle
  • Intramuscular
    • Shake well before use
    • If using a multidose vial, draw up each dose using a separate sterile needle and syringe
    • Use different injection sites if concomitant use of other vaccines is required
    • Preferred injection site in children, 6 to 35 months, is the anterolateral aspect of the thigh
    • Preferred injection site in adults and older children is the deltoid muscle
    • Do not administer in the gluteal area or areas where there may be a major nerve trunk

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: no specific monitoring has been determined

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient that influenza infection may still occur after vaccine, but symptoms should be less severe. Vaccine does not prevent other respiratory infections.
  • Drug may cause myalgia, fever, fatigue, headaches, malaise, diarrhea, vomiting, and injection-site reactions.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of Guillain-Barr syndrome (eg, myalgia, ataxia, muscle weakness, or paresthesias).
  • Advise patient to report severe or unusual adverse reactions following vaccination.
